skill.name: dask
skill.description: Distributed computing for larger-than-RAM pandas/NumPy workflows. Use when you need to scale existing pandas/NumPy code beyond memory or across clusters. Best for parallel file processing, distributed ML, integration with existing pandas code. For out-of-core analytics on single machine use vaex; for in-memory speed use polars.
skill.summary: Distributed computing for larger-than-RAM pandas/NumPy workflows. Use when you need to scale existin...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing no executable code. All 440 static findings are false positives triggered by markdown syntax and legitimate computing terminology. The analyzer misinterpreted backticks in code formatting as shell execution, and common terms like 'command', 'control', 'md5', 'connect' in documentation as security threats.

content.user_title: Scale pandas and NumPy with Dask distributed computing
content.value_statement: Process datasets larger than RAM using parallel computation. This skill enables scaling existing pandas and NumPy code across multiple cores or clusters without major rewrites. Ideal for handling terabyte-scale data on laptops or distributed clusters.
actual_capabilities: Scale pandas operations to larger-than-memory datasets using Dask DataFrames
Parallelize NumPy array computations across multiple cores with Dask Arrays
Process unstructured text and JSON data with Dask Bags
Build custom parallel workflows with immediate task execution using Dask Futures
Configure execution schedulers (threads, processes, distributed) for optimal performance
Convert between Dask collections and integrate with pandas, NumPy, XArray, and scikit-learn
limitations: Does not implement all pandas/NumPy functions (some require workarounds)
Operations requiring global data views may not parallelize well
Millions of tiny tasks incur scheduling overhead (~1ms per task)
Requires understanding of chunking strategies for optimal performance

use_cases.target_user: Data scientists working with large tabular data
use_cases.title: Analyze datasets larger than RAM
use_cases.description: Process CSV and Parquet files exceeding available memory using familiar pandas syntax

use_cases.title: Scale preprocessing for ML pipelines
use_cases.description: Parallelize data transformation and feature engineering across clusters

use_cases.title: Compute with arrays beyond memory limits
use_cases.description: Perform linear algebra and array operations on datasets too large for NumPy

prompt_templates.title: Basic DataFrame scaling
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to read multiple CSV files larger than RAM using Dask DataFrames and compute the mean of a column grouped by category

prompt_templates.title: Array parallelization
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create a Dask Array with 100 million elements, chunk it appropriately, and perform matrix multiplication and SVD decomposition

prompt_templates.title: Custom parallel workflows
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up a Dask distributed client and show me how to submit custom functions that depend on each other using futures

prompt_templates.title: Performance optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: My Dask computation is slow. Show me how to use the synchronous scheduler for debugging, check task graph size, and configure optimal chunk sizes

output_examples.input: Help me process a 50GB CSV file that exceeds my RAM
output: Use Dask DataFrames to read and process the data in chunks:
â€¢ Read with: ddf = dd.read_csv('large_file.csv') - lazy loading
â€¢ Filter early: ddf = ddf[ddf['year'] == 2024] - reduces data before compute
â€¢ Target ~100MB chunks for good parallelization
â€¢ Monitor with dashboard: client = Client() then open the provided URL

best_practices: Let Dask handle data loading - avoid pandas.read_csv then converting to Dask
Compute once at the end - chain operations and call .compute() single time
Choose appropriate chunk sizes (~100MB per chunk) for your worker memory
Pre-scatter large data once and reuse across multiple tasks
anti_patterns: Calling compute() repeatedly in loops - defeats parallelization
Building task graphs with millions of tiny tasks - excessive overhead
Using threads for pure Python code - GIL contention, use processes instead
Loading all data locally then handing to Dask - defeats distributed purpose

faq.question: When should I use Dask instead of pandas?
faq.answer: Use Dask when your dataset exceeds available RAM, operations take significant time, or you need to scale to multiple machines.

faq.question: How do I choose chunk sizes?
faq.answer: Target ~100MB per chunk so workers can hold 10 chunks per core. Too small causes overhead, too large causes memory issues.

faq.question: What scheduler should I use?
faq.answer: Threads for NumPy/Pandas, processes for pure Python code, distributed for clusters and monitoring dashboard.

faq.question: Does Dask replace pandas?
faq.answer: No - Dask implements most pandas API but not all functions. Use pandas for data fitting in memory, Dask for larger data.

faq.question: How do I debug Dask computations?
faq.answer: Use synchronous scheduler with dask.config.set(scheduler='synchronous') for pdb debugging, or test on small samples first.

faq.question: Can I use Dask with scikit-learn?
faq.answer: Yes via dask-ml which provides scikit-learn compatible estimators for parallel training and grid search.
